head.title: Enregistrement d'un rendu de carton dans un fichier OGG (comme MP3)
Recording the aprint book sound rendering in a mp3 like file format (OGG)

body.h1: Enregistrer le rendu sonore d'APrint dans un fichier OGG (comme les fichiers MP3)
Recording the aprint book sound rendering in a mp3 like file format (OGG)
body.p: APrint has a functionnality to record the rendering of a midi file, using the instruments defined with APrint in an audio file format that can be shared without giving the Midi file. Thoses files could also be used in MP3 players, ipods ..

APrint a une fonctionnalité permettant d'enregistrer le rendu APrint d'un fichier midi dans un format audio pouvant etre utilisé par ailleurs. Cela permet également de pouvoir partager un morceau avec d'autres utilisateurs sans envoyer le fichier midi, et plus simple d'utilisation qu'un logiciel midi.

Le format OGG est un format de fichier audio utilisant une méthode de compression similaire à MP3, mais ayant une plus grande qualité. Ce format est généralement préféré au MP3 car il est libre de droit. La plupart des logiciels permettant d'écouter des fichiers MP3 sont maintenant capable de lire nativement ce type de fichiers. Si le logiciel que vous utilisez ne sait pas lire le format OGG, vous pouvez visiter la page wikipedia sur le sujet, celle ci vous redirigera vers les plugins fournissant cette possibilité pour votre logiciel d'écoute.
Page Wikipedia sur le Format OGG

Ogg is a free, open standard container format maintained by the Xiph.Org Foundation. The creators of the Ogg format claim that it is unrestricted by software patents and is designed to provide for efficient streaming and manipulation of high quality digital multimedia.
The name ‘Ogg’ refers to the file format which can multiplex a number of separate independent free and open source codecs for audio, video, text (such as subtitles), and metadata.
In the Ogg multimedia framework, Theora provides a lossy video layer, while the music-oriented Vorbis codec most commonly acts as the audio layer. The human speech compression codec Speex, lossless audio compression codec FLAC, and OggPCM may also act as audio layers.
The term ‘Ogg’ is commonly used to refer to audio file format Ogg Vorbis, that is, Vorbis-encoded audio in the Ogg container. Previously, the .ogg file extension was used for any content distributed within Ogg, but as of 2007, the Xiph.Org Foundation requests that .ogg be used only for Vorbis due to backward compatibility concerns. The Xiph.Org Foundation decided to create a new set of file extensions and media types to describe different types of content such as .oga for audio only files, .ogv for video with or without sound (including Theora), and .ogx for applications.
The current version of the Xiph.Org Foundation's reference implementation, released on June 23, 2009, is libogg 1.1.4. Another version, libogg2, has been in development, but is awaiting a rewrite as of 2008[4]. Both software libraries are free software, released under the new BSD license. Ogg reference implementation was separated from Vorbis on September 2, 2000.
Because the format is free, and its reference implementation is non-copylefted, Ogg's various codecs have been incorporated into a number of different free and proprietary media players, both commercial and non-commercial, as well as portable media players and GPS receivers from different manufacturers.

body.h2: How to create the OGG File
body.p: Après avoir sélectionner un fichier midi, puis un instrument, la page de présentation du carton vous propose un bouton permettant de faire cela
Once you have selected a midi file, an instrument and whatching the book view, a top button permit to create the OGG File.

body.p: This function will ask for a file name to save. The processing can take a couple of seconds.
une fois sélectionné, le logiciel demandera alors un nom et un emplacement de fichier. Le temps de traitement de la fonction peut prendre quelques secondes.
